column1: Day 1 AM · We believe rhyming statements are more truthful. ('What sobriety conceals, alcohol reveals.')
Day 1 PM · You can't tickle yourself—your cerebellum predicts the touch and cancels the sensation.
Day 2 AM · Yawning is contagious only among people who feel emotionally close.
Day 2 PM · We remember the first and last items in a list best. It’s called the serial‑position effect.
Day 3 AM · Your brain fills your blind spot so well you rarely notice you’re missing data.
Day 3 PM · We overestimate how much people notice us. This is called the spotlight effect.
Day 4 AM · We make decisions based on framing—even if it’s the same fact. (90 % fat‑free vs 10 % fat.)
Day 4 PM · We store feelings, not facts—hence emotionally wrong memories feel right.
Day 5 AM · We mimic others' facial expressions unconsciously (mirroring) to build rapport.
Day 5 PM · Our working memory tops out around seven items—that’s why phone numbers are short.
Day 6 AM · We believe rhyming statements are more truthful. ('What sobriety conceals, alcohol reveals.')
Day 6 PM · You can't tickle yourself—your cerebellum predicts the touch and cancels the sensation.

Day 166 AM · We believe rhyming statements are more truthful. ('What sobriety conceals, alcohol reveals.')
Day 166 PM · You can't tickle yourself—your cerebellum predicts the touch and cancels the sensation.
Day 167 AM · Yawning is contagious only among people who feel emotionally close.
Day 167 PM · We remember the first and last items in a list best. It’s called the serial‑position effect.
Day 168 AM · Your brain fills your blind spot so well you rarely notice you’re missing data.
Day 168 PM · We overestimate how much people notice us. This is called the spotlight effect.
Day 169 AM · We make decisions based on framing—even if it’s the same fact. (90 % fat‑free vs 10 % fat.)
Day 169 PM · We store feelings, not facts—hence emotionally wrong memories feel right.

Day 330 AM · We mimic others' facial expressions unconsciously (mirroring) to build rapport.
Day 330 PM · Our working memory tops out around seven items—that’s why phone numbers are short.
Day 331 AM · We believe rhyming statements are more truthful. ('What sobriety conceals, alcohol reveals.')
Day 331 PM · You can't tickle yourself—your cerebellum predicts the touch and cancels the sensation.
Day 332 AM · Yawning is contagious only among people who feel emotionally close.
Day 332 PM · We remember the first and last items in a list best. It’s called the serial‑position effect.
Day 333 AM · Your brain fills your blind spot so well you rarely notice you’re missing data.
Day 333 PM · We overestimate how much people notice us. This is called the spotlight effect.
